Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Christopher Ortega of the University of Houston to conduct a research project in materials science during the summer of 2013 at Yunnan University in Kunming, Yunnan. The project title is "The Synthesis and Characterization of a Nanostructured Composite Photoanode used for Solar Assisted Hydrogen Generation." The host scientist is Dr. Zhu Liu.

This project works toward the synthesis of a composite photoanode consisting of a nano-mesoporous Tungsten Trioxide film, that is electrochemically coated with hematite. The nanoporous Tungsten Trioxide film provides a scaffold for the hematite resulting in a nanoporous network, with an increased surface area that allows for higher efficiency in hydrogen generation. Precise electrochemical pulse deposition is used to coat the nanoporous network of the WO3 film with a highly uniform hematite film. The use of a composite structure, alongside a nanoporous structure allows for a highly efficient photoanode, capable of generating hydrogen when exposed to solar light. This research is novel clean energy research topic since hydrogen is the required fuel for fuel cells, but the majority of hydrogen is currently generated using fossil fuels, making hydrogen fuel cells a non-fully clean energy process. By developing a renewable method of generating hydrogen, it is possible to have a completely renewable energy generation process.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this project allows for both Dr. Zhu Liu and the Fellow to disseminate the results of the research at conferences and workshops in the United States and the host country. This ensures that the research impacts a wider audience in the countries that have the highest need for clean energy. The research conducted will also be shared with the Fellow's home university, through seminars and department presentations showing the benefits of international collaboration, international culture exchange, and the value of clean energy fuel synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) granted me the opportunity to collaborate with Professor Zhu Liu and her research team at Yunnan University. The goal of the project was to explore the electrochemical synthesis of nanostructured photoanodes, and to engage in cultural exchange between our two cultures, which represent the most dominant superpowers in our generation.

To give a background over the project, photoanodes are semiconductors that use sunlight to aid in the electrolysis of water into hydrogen and oxygen molecules. The electrolysis occurs by two half reactions, the first being the oxidation of water into hydrogen ion, water molecules and free electrons. And the other being the reduction of hydrogen ions and electrons into hydrogen molecules. The photoanode is a n-type semiconductor that is stable in water and that acts as the anode for this process, specifically the photoanode acts as the negative electrode and aids in the water oxidation half-reaction. The development of solar driven hydrogen/oxygen production from water would allow for a new form of clean and renewable fuel. Solar assisted hydrogen production has become quite novel since it does allow for the generation of a storable fuel, instead of an electric charge as in photovoltaics. This technology would allow for a new method of generating hydrogen for both commercial and industrial applications, the foremost being a method of generating the H2 needed to operate fuel cells, a potential replacement for the gasoline engine in automobiles. 

The photoanodes that we developed were composed composed of nano-mesoporous WO3 coated with a nano-thin layer of α-Fe2O3. This bi-layered structure allowed for several mutual benefits, that are not possible with a single-layered semiconductor material. First, by utilizing two semiconductors with differing band-gaps, a larger percentage of the wavelength of incident sunlight could be harvested.  Secondly, due to the band-structure that occurs between WO3/α-Fe2O3, the photoanode has a more efficient carrier generation and mobility, and a retarded recombination of electron/hole pairs. The nanostructure of the mesoporous WO3 also allows for an increase in surface area, which thereby increases the effective reaction area of the electrochemical process.

A novel method that we were using to synthesize these photoanodes, was through a combination of electrochemical synthesis and annealing. The process that we developed allowed for the synthesis of these composite nanostructured photoanodes, without the need for toxic chemicals, vacuum systems, or highly expensive equipment, which is common with most photoanodes currently in development. The main driving force for this project was the development of a truly clean energy, that would be beneficial to both the United States and China, the world's biggest energy consumers and polluters. 

We were successful in that we were able to synthesize nano-mesoporous WO3 through annodization followed by thermal annealing, and subsequently form WO3/α-Fe2O3 photoanodes using light assisted electrodeposition of Fe followed by thermal annealing. The light assisted electrodeposition was a crucial technique that was utilized in this project, since it allowed for a more uniform and thinner coating of α-Fe2O3. These photoanodes were structurally characterized to verify their composition and topography, but the electrochemical and phtoanode characterization is still too premature to report. Future work and collaborations are being developed form this project to further the advancement of photoanodes and clean energy.
